content.description: Many ways up. Stay left of crack (Balder).
content.protection: Typical great falls TR anchor. Lots of trees and natural pro.
content.location: Just to the left/downstream of Balder

content.description: Start a few feet right of Conroy. Climb either of the two arching cracks that converge at the overhang. Pull the overhang and finish over easier rock.
Same start as for Dr. Needlepoint. Ascend the wall to the left.
Face just to the left of "Dr. Needlepoint" and right of "Blitzkrieg".
content.protection: Typical great falls TR anchor. Lots of trees and natural pro.
content.location: Face on the Slightly overhanging wall where you can find the famous route "Dr. Needlepoint".

content.description: Start approximately 150 yards downstream from Armbuster and 50 feet upstream from the Needlepoint Corner. Descend the corner behind a flake onto additional flakes. Descend left to easier rock.   Note: This is a very awkward and potentially dangerous downclimb.  It is also the easiest descent for the climbs between the Inclined Plane and Blitzkreig.
content.location: Approximately 150 yards downstream from Armbuster and 50 feet upstream from the Needlepoint Corner.

content.description: Start at the base of the large corner downstream from the descent route - climb the corner.
Start five feet left of Blitzkreig arete. Climb the broken corner and flakes up face to left of arete.
Start 20 feet to the right of "Bridge Too Far" and climb up and to right of low angle face.
content.protection: Typical great falls TR anchor. Lots of trees and natural pro.
content.location: The far right/upstream climb at the Doc.

content.description: Crack system up the center of a small wall. Lots of options maybe too many because it does not let up.
content.protection: A good lead route as well as a top rope.
content.location: This is the Dr. Needlepoint cliff.

content.description: Few hard moves right off the ground.
content.protection: Typical great falls TR anchor. Lots of trees and natural pro.
content.location: Start at small flake to the left of "Conroy".

content.description: Variation of "Dr. Needlepoint" using only the left crack.
content.protection: Typical great falls TR anchor. Lots of trees and natural pro. Pay close attention to anchor placement and abrasive edges.
content.location: Same as "Dr. Needlepoint". Begin on small ledge left of the corner and follow up center/left crack.

content.description: Easier route with great crack and slight overhang.
content.protection: Typical great falls TR anchor. Lots of trees and natural pro.
content.location: Start below triangular overhang/two cracks. Move through cracks and up through overhang.

content.description: Fly past a crimpy crux about 10 feet up on the arete that defines Dr. Needlepoint face.
content.protection: Typical great falls TR anchor. Lots of trees and natural pro.
content.location: To the left of Dr. Needlepoint.

content.description: Climb the prominent right facing crack and corner. This easy route sandwiched between two moderate/hard routes makes great terrain to challenge beginning climbers of all abilities.
content.protection: Typical great falls TR anchor. Lots of trees and natural pro.
content.location: Far left/downstream on Dr. Needlepoint wall. Directly in front of last large sandy ledge before starting scramble around to harder, slightly separated section of Dr Needlepoint.

content.description: Same as "A Bridge Too Far" but traverse right and finish by pulling the roof and "hanging to finish".
content.protection: Typical great falls TR anchor. Lots of trees and natural pro.
content.location: Left of "Inclined Plane" and below high overhang.

content.description: Many variations make this a fun fairly stiff route. Start right on the ramp and move left into crack before overhang.
content.protection: Typical great falls TR anchor. Lots of trees and natural pro.
content.location: Left of "Inclined Plane" and below high overhang.

content.description: The Dr. Needlepoint area begins about 50 yards downstream from the last of the Cornice area climbs.
